section.title: A Financial Interpretation of s_{\angln}
section.p: So far, we derived the formula for a_{\angln} and used that formula and our work with timelines to obtain the formulas for a_{\angl{\infty}} and s_{\angln}.
In this section, we are going to use timeline reasoning and financial intuition to find the formulas for a_{\angl\infty} and s_{\angln} (and thereby, for a_{\angln}).

introduction.p: We begin with perpetuities. Perpetuities can be thought of as paying the interest off on a loan, and only the interest, forever.

task.p: Suppose we borrow P at an annual interest rate \iota, and pay the interest off (and no principal) annually forever. The annual payment is K. Write a formula for K.
Which variable in this formula is actually Ka_{\angl\infty}?

introduction.p: We are now going to use perpetuities to examine annuities.

task.p: Suppose we have two perpetuities with payments of K. Perpetuity 1 starts making payments at the end of the first year, and Perpetuity 2 starts making payments at the end of year n+1 (at time n+1). Both are valued with the same effective interest rate \iota.
Make two timelines - one for each perpetuity. Include times 0, 1, 2, n, n+1, and n+2 in both timelines.
Make a new timeline representing what we would get if we subtracted the Perpetuity 2 payments from Perpetuity 1 (subtract the payments at each point in time).
What does your new timeline represent financially?
Find the value at time n of Perpetuities 1 and 2, then subtract and simplify. What do we get? Do you recognize this?
Find any missing annuity immediate or perpetuity immediate formulas.
Could you see using this approach to reconstruct annuity-immediate formulas if you do not remember them? Why or why not?
